sn2.25:1.2: At one time several mendicants were staying in the Kosalan lands, in a wilderness hut on the slopes of the Himalayas. They were restless, insolent, fickle, scurrilous, loose-tongued, unmindful, lacking situational awareness and immersion, with straying minds and undisciplined faculties.
sn2.25:2.1: Then on the fifteenth day sabbath the god Jantu went up to those mendicants and addressed them in verse:
sn2.25:3.5: Knowing that the world was impermanent
sn2.25:3.6: they made an end of suffering.
sn2.25:4.1: But now they’ve made themselves hard to look after,
sn2.25:4.3: They eat and eat and then lie down,
sn2.25:4.4: unconscious in the homes of others.
sn2.25:5.1: Having raised my joined palms to the Saṅgha,
sn2.25:5.2: I speak here only about certain people.
sn2.25:5.4: just like those who have passed away.
